canonical_explanation.text: Electric charge is a fundamental property of matter. There are two types of charges: positive and negative. Like charges repel and unlike charges attract. Objects can be charged by friction (rubbing), conduction (contact), and induction (nearby charged object). Conductors allow charges to flow through them, while insulators do not. Semiconductors have intermediate properties. An electroscope is used to detect the presence and type of charge. Lightning is a natural phenomenon caused by the buildup and discharge of static electricity in clouds. Lightning conductors protect buildings by providing a safe path for the electric discharge to reach the ground.
rules: Two types of charges: positive and negative
Like charges repel, unlike charges attract
Charging by friction: rubbing transfers electrons
Charging by induction: no contact, charge redistribution
Lightning: discharge of accumulated static electricity
Lightning conductor: protects buildings from lightning

questions.question_text: How many types of electric charges are there?
questions.explanation_correct: There are two types of electric charges - positive and negative. This is a fundamental property of matter. Objects can be charged by various methods, and these charges can either attract or repel each other depending on whether they are of the same or opposite type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While there are some different types of electrical properties that materials can have, such as conductors, insulators, and semiconductors, the fundamental electric charges in nature are limited to only two types - positive and negative. The other options of one, three, or four types of charges are incorrect, as the number of basic electric charges is always two.

questions.question_text: What happens when two like charges are brought close together?
questions.explanation_correct: Two like charges (either both positive or both negative) will repel each other when brought close together. This is because like charges have the same type of electric charge, and these charges of the same type push apart from each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When two like charges are brought close together, they do not attract each other. This is because charges of the same type (positive or negative) have a repulsive force between them, and they will push away from each other. The correct option is that they will repel, not attract or neutralize each other.

questions.question_text: Charging by friction involves:
questions.explanation_correct: Charging by friction involves the transfer of electrons between the two objects being rubbed together. When you rub two objects, such as a balloon and your hair, electrons can move from one object to the other, creating a net positive or negative charge on each object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charging by friction does not involve the transfer of protons or neutrons. Protons are the positively charged particles in the nucleus of an atom, and neutrons are the neutral particles in the nucleus. During friction, only the outermost electrons of the atoms in the objects being rubbed move from one object to the other, causing the objects to become charged.

questions.question_text: Materials that allow electric charges to flow through them are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Conductors are materials that allow electric charges to flow through them easily. This is because conductors have free-flowing electrons that can move through the material, allowing electricity to pass through.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insulators are materials that do not allow electric charges to flow through them. This is because insulators have tightly-bound electrons that cannot move freely, preventing electricity from passing through. Semiconductors and resistors are not the correct answer, as they have intermediate or high resistance to the flow of electric charges.

questions.question_text: Which instrument is used to detect the presence of electric charge?
questions.explanation_correct: An electroscope is used to detect the presence of electric charge. It has two leaves that move apart when an object with electric charge is brought near it, indicating the presence of the charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A thermometer is used to measure temperature, a barometer is used to measure atmospheric pressure, and an ammeter is used to measure electric current. None of these instruments are used to detect the presence of electric charge. The correct instrument for this purpose is the electroscope, which uses the movement of two leaves to indicate the presence of electric charge.

questions.question_text: When a plastic comb is rubbed with dry hair, the comb becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When a plastic comb is rubbed with dry hair, the comb becomes negatively charged. This is because the friction between the comb and hair causes electrons to transfer from the hair to the comb, giving the comb a net negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The comb does not become positively charged because the friction causes electrons to move from the hair to the comb, not the other way around. The comb also does not become neutral, as it has a net negative charge. Finally, the comb does not become magnetic, as static electricity is a different type of force than magnetism.

questions.question_text: Lightning occurs due to:
questions.explanation_correct: Lightning occurs due to the discharge of accumulated static electricity in clouds. As water vapor in the clouds gets charged, it builds up a large amount of static electricity. When the charge difference between the clouds and the ground becomes too large, it leads to a sudden discharge, resulting in a bright flash of lightning.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning does not occur due to the flow of water in clouds, magnetic storms, or nuclear reactions. While these phenomena can be related to weather patterns, they do not directly cause the buildup and discharge of static electricity that leads to lightning. The correct answer is that lightning is caused by the discharge of accumulated static electricity in the clouds.

questions.question_text: A lightning conductor is made of:
questions.explanation_correct: Lightning conductors are made of copper or aluminum because these metals are good conductors of electricity. They can safely carry the large electric current from a lightning strike down to the ground, preventing damage to the building.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning conductors are not made of rubber, plastic, or wood. These materials are insulators, which means they do not allow electricity to flow through them easily. Insulators would not be able to safely conduct the large electric current from a lightning strike, putting the building at risk of damage.

questions.question_text: In charging by induction:

options.text: The charged object touches the uncharged object
Charges are redistributed without direct contact

questions.explanation_correct: In charging by induction, the charged object does not need to touch the uncharged object. The charges in the uncharged object are redistributed due to the presence of the nearby charged object, without any direct contact between the two objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charging by induction does not involve the transfer of electrons by friction, as in the case of charging by rubbing. It also does not require both objects to be conductors - an insulator can also be charged by induction, as long as there is a nearby charged object that can induce a charge in it.

questions.question_text: Semiconductors are materials that:

options.text: Have conductivity between conductors and insulators
Only conduct at very high temperatures

questions.explanation_correct: Semiconductors have conductivity that falls between conductors and insulators. They can conduct electricity under certain conditions, but not as well as conductors like metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Semiconductors are not always good conductors like metals, nor are they always poor conductors like insulators. They have an in-between conductivity that can be controlled and adjusted, which makes them useful in electronic devices.

questions.question_text: Unlike charges attract each other.
questions.explanation_correct: Unlike charges attract each other because opposite charges are drawn to one another. Positive and negative charges have a natural attraction, so they will come together and stick to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is a common misconception that like charges attract each other. However, this is not true. Like charges, whether positive or negative, actually repel each other. It is unlike charges, one positive and one negative, that are attracted to each other and stick together.

questions.question_text: Rubber is a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: Rubber is a good insulator, not a conductor. Insulators do not allow electric charges to flow through them easily, unlike conductors. This means that rubber is not a good conductor of electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rubber is a type of insulator, not a conductor. Conductors are materials that allow electric charges to move freely through them, such as metals. Insulators, like rubber, do not allow charges to flow easily. This is why rubber is not a good conductor of electricity.

questions.question_text: During a thunderstorm, it is safe to stand under a tall tree.
questions.explanation_correct: It is not safe to stand under a tall tree during a thunderstorm. Tall objects like trees can attract lightning, which can be very dangerous. Lightning strikes can travel down the tree and into the ground, putting anyone standing nearby at risk of getting electrocuted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think it is safe to stand under a tree during a thunderstorm because the tree is tall and might attract the lightning away from them. However, this is a dangerous misconception. Trees are conductive and can actually act as a path for the lightning to travel down and reach the ground, putting anyone near the tree at risk of getting struck by the lightning.

questions.question_text: When a charged object is brought near an electroscope, the gold leaves diverge.
questions.explanation_correct: When a charged object is brought near an electroscope, the gold leaves of the electroscope diverge (move apart) because the charges in the electroscope get redistributed due to the presence of the external charged object, causing the leaves to be attracted to the sides of the electroscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be that the gold leaves of the electroscope do not diverge when a charged object is brought near it. This is because the charges in the electroscope get redistributed due to the presence of the external charged object, causing the leaves to be attracted to the sides of the electroscope, making them diverge.

questions.question_text: The two types of electric charges are positive and ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The two types of electric charges are positive and negative. This is because electric charge comes in two varieties - positive and negative. Objects can have a net positive charge, a net negative charge, or be electrically neutral with no net charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The two types of electric charges are positive and negative. The answer 'negative' is correct because electric charge comes in two varieties - positive and negative. Positive charge is the type of charge that glass rods and other objects acquire when rubbed with silk, while negative charge is the type of charge acquired by rubber rods when rubbed with fur. Objects can have a net positive charge, a net negative charge, or be electrically neutral with no net charge.

questions.question_text: Charging an object by rubbing it with another object is called charging by ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Charging an object by rubbing it with another object is called charging by friction. When you rub two objects together, the friction causes electrons to transfer from one object to the other, creating a static electric charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charging an object by rubbing it with another object is not called charging by 'conduction' or 'induction'. The correct term is 'friction'. Friction is the force that occurs when two surfaces are rubbed together, and this process can cause the transfer of electrons, leading to a static electric charge on the object.

questions.question_text: A ___ conductor protects buildings from lightning by providing a safe path to the ground.
questions.explanation_correct: A lightning conductor protects buildings from lightning by providing a safe path for the electric discharge to reach the ground. Lightning is a natural phenomenon caused by the buildup and discharge of static electricity in clouds. The lightning conductor, made of a metal like copper, gives the electricity a low-resistance path to flow through and avoid damaging the building.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'lightning' conductor, not just a regular conductor. A lightning conductor is a special type of conductor that is used to protect buildings from the harmful effects of lightning strikes. It is made of a metal like copper and is designed to safely direct the electric discharge from a lightning strike into the ground, preventing damage to the building.

questions.question_text: A gold leaf ___ is used to detect the presence and type of electric charge.
questions.explanation_correct: A gold leaf electroscope is used to detect the presence and type of electric charge. It consists of two thin gold leaves that move apart when a charged object is brought near, indicating the presence of an electric charge. This makes the gold leaf electroscope a useful tool for detecting and identifying electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'electroscope'. An electroscope is a device used to detect the presence and type of electric charge. It works by having two thin metal leaves that will move apart when a charged object is brought near, showing that there is an electric charge present. This makes the electroscope a very helpful tool for understanding static electricity.

questions.question_text: Arrange the events in lightning formation:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of events in lightning formation is: 1) Clouds develop opposite charges, 2) The electric field becomes strong enough, and 3) The lightning discharge occurs. This is because the buildup of opposite charges in the clouds creates a strong electric field, which eventually leads to the lightning discharge to balance the charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 1) Lightning discharge occurs, 2) Clouds develop opposite charges, 3) Electric field becomes strong enough. This is wrong because the lightning discharge cannot occur before the clouds develop opposite charges and the electric field becomes strong enough. The lightning is caused by the strong electric field, which is created by the separation of charges in the clouds.

questions.question_text: Arrange the three methods of charging:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is Friction, Conduction, Induction because this reflects the increasing complexity of the charging process. Friction is the simplest method, where rubbing two objects together causes a transfer of electrons and charging. Conduction is more complex, involving direct contact between the object and a charged source. Induction is the most complex, where the object is charged by the mere presence of a nearby charged object, without any direct contact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Induction, Friction, Conduction. This is not correct because Induction is the most complex charging method, requiring only the presence of a nearby charged object, while Friction and Conduction involve more direct contact between the objects. Friction is simpler than Conduction, as it just requires rubbing the objects together rather than making direct contact with a charged source.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of electric charge is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C). This is because charge is a fundamental property of matter, and the coulomb is the standard unit used to measure the amount of charge an object has.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is Coulomb (C), not Volt (V), Ampere (A), or Ohm (Î©). Volt is the unit for electric potential, Ampere is the unit for electric current, and Ohm is the unit for electrical resistance. Coulomb is the specific unit used to measure the amount of electric charge, which is the fundamental property of matter that we are discussing here.

questions.question_text: An atom is electrically neutral because it has:

options.text: Equal numbers of protons and electrons

questions.explanation_correct: An atom is electrically neutral because it has an equal number of protons (with positive charge) and electrons (with negative charge) inside it. This means the total positive and negative charges within the atom cancel each other out, making the atom overall neutral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A and B are incorrect because an atom needs both protons and electrons to be electrically neutral. Option D is also incorrect because an atom does contain charged particles like protons and electrons, even though the overall charge is neutral. The correct option is C, which states that an atom has equal numbers of protons and electrons, making the total charge zero and the atom electrically neutral.

questions.question_text: When a glass rod is rubbed with silk, the glass rod becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When a glass rod is rubbed with silk, the glass rod becomes positively charged. This is because the silk material has a tendency to lose electrons, leaving the glass rod with a surplus of positive charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The glass rod does not become negatively charged or neutral when rubbed with silk. This is because the friction between the glass and silk causes electrons to transfer from the silk to the glass, making the glass rod positively charged. The glass rod also does not become magnetic, as magnetism is a different property of matter.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an insulator?
questions.explanation_correct: Plastic is an insulator, which means it does not allow electric charges to flow through it. Insulators like plastic, glass, and wood do not have free-flowing electrons and so they block the movement of electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper, silver, and aluminum are all conductors, which means they allow electric charges to flow through them easily. Conductors have free-flowing electrons that can carry electric charges. However, plastic is an insulator that does not allow charges to flow through it, so it is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Electrons carry:
questions.explanation_correct: Electrons have a negative electric charge, so the correct answer is B. Negative charge. Electrons are fundamental particles that make up the atoms of all matter, and they have a constant negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electrons do not carry a positive charge (option A) or a variable charge (option D). Electrons have a fixed, negative charge. They are not neutral (option C) either, as they are the particles that carry the negative charge in an atom.

questions.question_text: Protons carry:
questions.explanation_correct: Protons carry a positive charge because they have a positive electrical charge. This is a fundamental property of protons, which are positively charged subatomic particles that make up the nucleus of an atom.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because electrons carry a negative charge, while neutrons have no charge. Protons are the only particles that have a positive charge. The correct answer is A, as protons always carry a positive charge, and this is an essential characteristic of protons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the best conductor of electricity?
questions.explanation_correct: Silver is the best conductor of electricity because it has a very low resistance to the flow of electric current. This means that electricity can move through silver very easily and with minimal energy loss.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wood, glass, and rubber are not good conductors of electricity. They are actually insulators, which means they do not allow electric current to flow through them easily. This is because these materials have a very high resistance to the flow of electricity. Silver, on the other hand, has a very low resistance and allows electric current to flow through it with ease, making it the best conductor among the options provided.

questions.question_text: Lightning conductors are installed on:
questions.explanation_correct: Lightning conductors are installed on tall buildings and structures because they are the most vulnerable to lightning strikes. Tall buildings and structures are more likely to be hit by lightning due to their height, so lightning conductors are used to safely divert the electrical discharge to the ground.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lightning conductors are not installed on short buildings, underground structures, or vehicles. Short buildings are less likely to be struck by lightning, and underground structures and vehicles are not as susceptible to direct lightning strikes. Lightning conductors are specifically designed to protect tall buildings and structures from the harmful effects of lightning.

questions.question_text: In an electroscope, the leaves are made of:
questions.explanation_correct: The leaves of an electroscope are made of gold or aluminum because these metals are good conductors of electricity. When an electroscope is charged, the charges flow through the metal leaves, causing them to repel each other and stand apart, indicating the presence of static electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The leaves of an electroscope are not made of rubber, plastic, or wood because these materials are insulators. Insulators do not allow electric charges to flow through them, so the leaves would not be able to move and indicate the presence of static electricity.

questions.question_text: Static electricity is the accumulation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Static electricity is the accumulation of stationary electric charges on a surface. This means the charges are not moving, but instead have built up on a material or object, creating an imbalance of positive and negative charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Static electricity is not the accumulation of moving charges, magnetic fields, or heat energy. Moving charges create electric current, which is different from static electricity. Magnetic fields and heat energy are also distinct physical phenomena from static electricity, which involves the buildup of electric charges on a surface.

questions.question_text: When you rub a balloon on your hair, it sticks to the wall because:

options.text: The balloon gets charged and induces opposite charge on the wall

questions.explanation_correct: When you rub a balloon on your hair, it becomes charged with static electricity. This induces an opposite charge on the wall, causing the balloon to stick to it due to the attractive force between the opposite charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The balloon does not become magnetic when rubbed on hair. It also does not get wet or make the wall sticky. The correct answer is that the balloon gets charged with static electricity, and this charge induces an opposite charge on the wall, leading to an attractive force that makes the balloon stick to the wall.

questions.question_text: In charging by conduction, charges are transferred by:
questions.explanation_correct: In charging by conduction, charges are transferred through direct physical contact between the object and a charged source. This allows the charges to flow from the charged source to the object, resulting in the object becoming charged as well.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charging by conduction involves the direct transfer of electric charges between two objects when they are in contact. This is different from charging by rubbing (friction) or bringing objects close without touching (induction). Heating an object does not directly result in the object becoming charged.

questions.question_text: The loud sound of thunder is caused by:

options.text: Rapid heating and expansion of air around lightning

questions.explanation_correct: The loud sound of thunder is caused by the rapid heating and expansion of air around the lightning bolt. The lightning creates a very high temperature that rapidly expands the surrounding air, creating a loud sound wave that we hear as thunder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The loud sound of thunder is not caused by the collision of clouds, falling rain, or wind. These other options do not create the intense heating and pressure changes that are the actual cause of the thunderous sound.

questions.question_text: When a positively charged rod is brought near a neutral electroscope, the leaves diverge because:

options.text: Both leaves get the same charge

questions.explanation_correct: When a positively charged rod is brought near a neutral electroscope, the leaves diverge because the rod induces a negative charge on the closer leaf and a positive charge on the farther leaf. This causes the leaves to repel each other, making them diverge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is correct because the rod transfers its positive charge to the electroscope, making both leaves get the same positive charge. This causes the leaves to repel each other and diverge. Options B, C, and D are incorrect because the leaves do not become neutral, magnetic, or have the rod's charge directly transferred to them.

questions.question_text: Why is it dangerous to use an umbrella during a thunderstorm?

options.text: The metal tip can attract lightning

questions.explanation_correct: The metal tip of an umbrella can act as a conductor and attract lightning during a thunderstorm. This makes it dangerous to use an umbrella as it can increase the risk of getting struck by lightning, which can be life-threatening.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Umbrellas do not attract rain, as that is a natural phenomenon caused by water droplets in the air. Umbrellas are also not insulators, as they can conduct electricity if they have a metal frame. The noise of thunder is not blocked by umbrellas either. The correct reason is that the metal tip of the umbrella can attract lightning, which makes it dangerous to use during a thunderstorm.

questions.question_text: When a charged plastic comb is brought near small pieces of paper, the paper is attracted because:

options.text: Induction causes temporary charge separation in paper

questions.explanation_correct: The paper is attracted to the charged plastic comb because of a process called induction. When the charged comb is brought near the paper, it causes temporary separation of positive and negative charges within the paper, making one side slightly positively charged and the other side slightly negatively charged. This temporary charge separation causes the paper to be attracted to the comb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The paper is not always positively charged, nor is it magnetic. The comb does not lose its charge when brought near the paper. The correct explanation is that the charge separation caused by induction in the paper is what makes it get attracted to the charged comb. The other options do not correctly explain the phenomenon.

questions.question_text: Inside a car is relatively safe during lightning because:

options.text: The metal body acts as a Faraday cage

questions.explanation_correct: The metal body of a car acts as a Faraday cage, which means it shields the inside from external electric fields. This prevents the buildup of static electricity inside the car, making it a safe place during a lightning storm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cars are not insulators, as they have a metal body that allows electricity to flow through it. The tires also do not absorb electricity, as they are made of rubber, which is an insulator. Additionally, cars do not attract lightning away, as they are not designed to do so. The correct answer is that the metal body of the car acts as a Faraday cage, shielding the inside from the external electric fields during a lightning storm.

questions.question_text: If an object gains electrons, it becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: If an object gains electrons, it becomes negatively charged. This is because electrons have a negative charge, so gaining more electrons gives the object an overall negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If an object gains electrons, it does not become positively charged (option A) because positive charge is caused by a lack of electrons, not an excess. It also does not become neutral (option C) or magnetic (option D) - gaining electrons specifically results in the object becoming negatively charged.

questions.question_text: When two objects are charged by friction, they acquire:
questions.explanation_correct: When two objects are rubbed together, they acquire opposite types of electric charge. One object becomes positively charged, while the other becomes negatively charged. This is because the friction causes electrons to be transferred from one object to the other, creating the opposite charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: If the two objects acquired the same type of charge, they would actually repel each other instead of attracting. This is because like charges (positive-positive or negative-negative) repel, while unlike charges (positive-negative) attract. The correct answer is that the two objects acquire opposite types of charge when charged by friction.

questions.question_text: An uncharged electroscope shows diverged leaves when a charged object is brought near it (without touching). This demonstrates:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Charging by induction. When a charged object is brought near an uncharged electroscope, the electric field of the charged object induces an opposite charge on the leaves of the electroscope, causing them to diverge and demonstrate the presence of the induced charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect options are not correct because: A) Charging by friction requires the electroscope to be rubbed with a charged object, which is not the case here. B) Charging by conduction requires the charged object to touch the electroscope, which is also not happening in this situation. D) Loss of charge would not cause the leaves to diverge, as the electroscope is initially uncharged.

questions.question_text: Neutrons have no electric charge.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true. Neutrons, which are subatomic particles found in the nucleus of an atom, have no electric charge. They are electrically neutral, unlike protons which have a positive charge and electrons which have a negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Neutrons have no electric charge, which means they are electrically neutral. This is because neutrons are made up of an equal number of up quarks and down quarks, which cancel out to give a net charge of zero. If neutrons had a positive or negative charge, they would interact with electric fields, which they do not.

questions.question_text: When charging by friction, protons are transferred from one object to another.
questions.explanation_correct: When charging by friction, electrons are transferred from one object to another, not protons. This is because electrons are more easily removed from the surface of an object than protons, which are tightly bound to the nucleus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'When charging by friction, protons are transferred from one object to another' is incorrect. During friction, electrons, not protons, are transferred between the two objects. This is because electrons are more loosely bound to the atoms and can be easily removed from the surface, while protons are tightly bound to the nucleus and cannot be easily removed.

questions.question_text: Metals are good conductors of electricity.
questions.explanation_correct: Metals are good conductors of electricity because they have free-flowing electrons that can carry an electric current through them easily. This allows charges to move freely through metals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think that metals are not good conductors of electricity. This is incorrect. Metals have a large number of free-moving electrons that can carry an electric current, making them excellent conductors. Non-metal materials like plastic or wood are poor conductors and do not allow charges to flow through them easily.

questions.question_text: Lightning always strikes the tallest object in an area.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'Lightning always strikes the tallest object in an area' is false. Lightning does not necessarily strike the tallest object, but rather the path of least resistance to the ground. This means lightning can strike various objects, not just the tallest one.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The common misconception is that lightning always strikes the tallest object in an area. However, this is not true. Lightning strikes the path of least resistance to the ground, which may not always be the tallest object. Other factors, such as the charge buildup and distribution in the clouds, also play a role in determining where lightning strikes.

questions.question_text: In charging by induction, the object being charged does not touch the charged object.
questions.explanation_correct: In charging by induction, the object being charged does not touch the charged object. Instead, the presence of the charged object causes the electrons in the neutral object to rearrange, creating a positive and negative side on the neutral object. This allows the object to become charged without direct contact.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Charging by induction does not require direct contact between the charged object and the object being charged. The charged object creates an electric field that causes the electrons in the neutral object to move around, resulting in one side becoming positively charged and the other negatively charged. This happens without the two objects touching each other.

questions.question_text: We see lightning before we hear thunder because light travels faster than sound.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is true because light travels much faster than sound. Light travels at about 3 x 10^8 m/s, while sound travels at only about 340 m/s. This means that light reaches our eyes first, and then we hear the sound of the thunder afterwards.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect reasoning would be that sound travels faster than light. This is not true - light is the fastest known form of energy transmission in the universe. The reason we see lightning before hearing thunder is that light travels much faster than sound, so the light from the lightning reaches our eyes first before the sound of the thunder reaches our ears.

questions.question_text: Like charges ___ and unlike charges attract.
questions.explanation_correct: Like charges repel each other because they have the same type of electric charge (either positive or negative). The electric fields of like charges push each other away, causing the repulsion. Unlike charges (one positive, one negative) attract each other because their electric fields pull towards each other, causing the attraction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'repel'. The statement 'like charges attract and unlike charges attract' is incorrect because it goes against the fundamental property of electric charges. In reality, like charges repel each other (e.g. two positive charges or two negative charges), while unlike charges (one positive, one negative) attract each other. This is because the electric fields of like charges push each other away, while the electric fields of unlike charges pull each other together.

questions.question_text: Materials that do not allow electric charges to flow through them are called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Materials that do not allow electric charges to flow through them are called insulators. Insulators, like plastic, wood, and glass, do not have free electrons that can move easily through the material. This means electricity cannot flow through them, so they are good at 'insulating' or preventing the flow of electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The materials that do not allow electric charges to flow through them are called 'insulators'. The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'insulators'. Some examples of insulators are plastic, glass, and rubber. Conductors, on the other hand, are materials that allow electric charges to flow freely through them, like metals. Insulators do not have many free electrons that can move easily, so they prevent the flow of electricity.

questions.question_text: An object becomes positively charged when it loses ___.
questions.explanation_correct: An object becomes positively charged when it loses electrons. This is because electrons have a negative charge, so if an object loses some of its electrons, it will have more positive charges (protons) than negative charges (electrons), making it overall positively charged.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'electrons'. When an object loses electrons, it becomes positively charged because it has more positive charges (protons) than negative charges (electrons). The accepted answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is a single word: 'electrons'.

questions.question_text: Silicon and germanium are examples of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Silicon and germanium are examples of semiconductors, which are materials that have properties in between those of conductors and insulators. They can be used to make electronic devices like transistors and integrated circuits.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'semiconductors'. Silicon and germanium are not conductors or insulators, but rather semiconductors - materials that have properties in between those two types of materials. Semiconductors are used to make many electronic devices like transistors and integrated circuits.

questions.question_text: The sound of ___ is produced by the rapid expansion of air due to lightning.
questions.explanation_correct: The sound of thunder is produced by the rapid expansion of air due to lightning. When lightning strikes, it heats the air around it to very high temperatures, causing the air to rapidly expand. This sudden expansion creates a shockwave that we hear as the sound of thunder.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sound of 'lightning' is not produced by the rapid expansion of air. Lightning is the bright flash of light seen during a thunderstorm, caused by the discharge of static electricity in the clouds. The correct answer is 'thunder', which is the sound produced by the rapid expansion of air due to the intense heat of the lightning strike.

questions.question_text: When a glass rod is rubbed with silk, the silk becomes ___ charged.
questions.explanation_correct: When a glass rod is rubbed with silk, the silk becomes negatively charged. This is because the friction between the glass and silk causes electrons to be transferred from the glass to the silk, giving the silk a negative charge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The silk becomes negatively charged when the glass rod is rubbed with it. This is because the friction causes electrons to move from the glass to the silk, making the silk have a negative charge. The correct answer format for this fill-in-the-blank question is 'negatively'.

questions.question_text: When the leaves of an electroscope come closer together, the charge is being ___.
questions.explanation_correct: When the leaves of an electroscope come closer together, it means the charge on the electroscope has been neutralized. This happens because the positive and negative charges have balanced each other out, causing the leaves to fall back down.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer would be 'increased'. This is not correct because when the leaves of an electroscope come closer together, it means the charge has been 'neutralized', not increased. Neutralized means the positive and negative charges have balanced each other out, causing the leaves to fall back down.

questions.question_text: A lightning conductor has a pointed tip at the ___ and is connected to the ground.
questions.explanation_correct: The lightning conductor has a pointed tip at the top because this helps concentrate the electric charge and facilitates the flow of electricity from the clouds to the ground. The pointed tip makes it easier for the electric discharge from the clouds to reach the ground safely.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lightning conductor should have a pointed tip at the top, not the bottom. This is because the pointed tip helps concentrate the electric charge and allows the electric discharge from the clouds to flow into the ground more easily. The correct answer format is 'top'.

questions.question_text: Arrange these materials from best conductor to best insulator:
questions.explanation_correct: Copper is the best conductor, meaning it allows electric charges to flow through it easily. Silicon is a semiconductor, which has properties between a conductor and an insulator. Rubber is an insulator, which does not allow charges to flow through it. Therefore, the correct order from best conductor to best insulator is Copper, Silicon, Rubber.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Rubber, Silicon, Copper. Rubber is an insulator and does not allow charges to flow, so it should be the last in the order. Silicon, being a semiconductor, should be in the middle. Copper is the best conductor, so it should be first in the order.

questions.question_text: Arrange the sequence of events during a lightning strike to a building with a lightning conductor:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct sequence is: Charge accumulates in clouds, Lightning strikes the conductor, Current flows safely to ground. This is because static electricity builds up in clouds first, which then leads to a lightning strike. The lightning conductor provides a safe path for the electric current to flow to the ground, preventing damage to the building.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect sequence is: Current flows safely to ground, Lightning strikes the conductor, Charge accumulates in clouds. This is wrong because the charge first builds up in the clouds, which then leads to the lightning strike. The lightning conductor does not cause the charge to build up, but rather provides a safe path for the current to flow to the ground after the lightning strike occurs.

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to test if an object is charged using an electroscope:
ordering_items: Bring object near the metal disc
correct_answer: Bring object near the metal disc
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is to first ensure the electroscope is uncharged, then bring the object near the metal disc, and finally observe if the leaves diverge. This is because the electroscope needs to be neutral initially in order to detect if the object is charged, and the divergence of the leaves indicates the presence and type of charge on the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to first observe if the leaves diverge, then bring the object near the metal disc, and finally ensure the electroscope is uncharged. This is wrong because the electroscope needs to be uncharged initially in order to detect the charge on the object. Observing the leaves first would not give a reliable result, as the electroscope may already be charged from a previous test.

questions.question_text: Arrange the process of charging an electroscope by induction:
ordering_items: Bring a charged rod near the electroscope
correct_answer: Bring a charged rod near the electroscope
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: bring the charged rod near the electroscope, ground the electroscope momentarily, then remove the charged rod. This is because the presence of the charged rod will induce an opposite charge on the electroscope, causing its leaves to diverge. Grounding allows the induced charge to flow away, and removing the rod leaves the electroscope charged with the same type of charge as the original rod.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: remove the charged rod, ground the electroscope momentarily, then bring the charged rod near the electroscope. This is wrong because removing the charged rod first would not induce any charge on the electroscope, so grounding it would not have any effect. The key step is to bring the charged rod near the electroscope first, to induce an opposite charge on it.

questions.question_text: How does charging by friction differ from charging by conduction?

options.text: Friction requires rubbing two objects together, while conduction requires direct contact with a charged object
Friction transfers protons, while conduction transfers electrons
Friction works only on metals, while conduction works on all materials
Friction produces positive charge only, while conduction produces negative charge only

questions.explanation_correct: Charging by friction involves rubbing two different materials together, which causes electrons to transfer from one surface to the other due to the frictional force. Charging by conduction involves directly touching an uncharged object with an already charged object, allowing electrons to flow from one to the other through contact. Both methods transfer electrons, but the mechanism of transfer is different.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is incorrect because both friction and conduction involve the transfer of electrons, not protons. Protons are tightly bound in the nucleus and do not move during charging. Option C is wrong because friction actually works better with insulators like plastic and rubber, not metals. Option D is incorrect because both methods can produce either positive or negative charges depending on the materials involved.

questions.question_text: How does a conductor differ from an insulator in terms of electron behaviour?

options.text: Conductors have no electrons, while insulators have many electrons
Conductors have free electrons that can move easily, while insulators have tightly bound electrons that cannot move freely
Conductors have only positive charges, while insulators have only negative charges
Conductors and insulators have the same electron behaviour but differ in size

questions.explanation_correct: The key difference lies in electron mobility. In conductors like copper and silver, the outermost electrons of atoms are loosely bound and can move freely throughout the material. These are called free electrons, and they allow electric charge to flow easily. In insulators like rubber and plastic, the electrons are tightly bound to their atoms and cannot move freely, which prevents the flow of charge through the material.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because both conductors and insulators contain electrons in their atoms. Option C is wrong because both conductors and insulators have atoms with protons, electrons, and neutrons. Option D is incorrect because size has nothing to do with the difference; it is the freedom of electron movement that distinguishes conductors from insulators.

questions.question_text: How does charging by induction differ from charging by conduction in terms of contact?

options.text: Induction requires rubbing, while conduction requires heating
Induction does not require physical contact, while conduction requires the charged object to touch the uncharged object
Induction works only in liquids, while conduction works only in solids
Both induction and conduction require direct physical contact

questions.explanation_correct: The main difference between induction and conduction is the requirement for physical contact. In charging by conduction, the charged object must directly touch the uncharged object so that electrons can flow between them. In charging by induction, the charged object is only brought near the uncharged object without touching it. The electric field of the charged object causes charge redistribution in the nearby object, inducing opposite charges on its surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because induction does not require rubbing (that is friction), and conduction does not require heating. Option C is wrong because both methods can work with solid objects. Option D is incorrect because induction specifically does not require contact, which is the defining difference between the two methods.

questions.question_text: How does the force between two positive charges differ from the force between a positive and a negative charge?

options.text: Two positive charges repel each other, while a positive and a negative charge attract each other
Two positive charges attract, while a positive and negative charge repel
There is no force in either case

questions.explanation_correct: Two positive charges are like charges, and like charges always repel each other. When brought close, they push away from each other. A positive charge and a negative charge are unlike charges, and unlike charges always attract each other. When brought close, they pull towards each other. This fundamental difference in force direction is one of the most important properties of electric charges.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because two positive charges (like charges) repel, they do not attract. Option C reverses the actual behaviour and is incorrect. Option D is wrong because there is always an electrostatic force between charged objects, whether attractive or repulsive.

questions.question_text: How does the charge distribution differ between the top and bottom of a thundercloud?

options.text: The top has negative charge and the bottom has positive charge
The top has positive charge and the bottom has negative charge
Both top and bottom have the same type of charge
Thunderclouds do not have any charge distribution

questions.explanation_correct: In a thundercloud, the lighter ice crystals carry positive charge and are pushed to the top by air currents, while the heavier water droplets and hailstones carry negative charge and accumulate at the bottom. This charge separation between the positive upper region and negative lower region creates a large electric field, which eventually leads to a lightning discharge when the field becomes strong enough.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A incorrectly reverses the charge distribution. Option C is wrong because the whole point of charge buildup in thunderclouds is that opposite charges separate to different regions. Option D is incorrect because the charge distribution in thunderclouds is precisely what causes lightning.

questions.question_text: A material has very few free electrons, does not allow charges to pass through it, and is commonly used to cover electrical wires for safety. This material is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The material described is an insulator. The three key features â very few free electrons, inability to allow charges to pass through, and use as a safety covering on wires â are all characteristic of insulators. Materials like rubber and PVC are commonly used to coat electrical wires to prevent electric shock, precisely because they do not allow charge to flow through them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because conductors have many free electrons and allow charges to flow easily. Option C is wrong because semiconductors have intermediate conductivity and are used in electronic components, not as wire coverings. Option D is incorrect because superconductors have zero resistance and allow perfect flow of charges, which is the opposite of the described properties.

questions.question_text: An object becomes charged when a nearby charged body causes redistribution of charges within it, without any physical contact. This method of charging is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The description matches charging by induction. The two defining features â charge redistribution without physical contact and the influence of a nearby charged body â are the hallmarks of electrostatic induction. In this process, the electric field of the charged body causes electrons in the nearby uncharged object to move, creating regions of positive and negative charge on the object's surface.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because charging by friction requires rubbing two surfaces together. Option B is wrong because charging by conduction requires direct physical contact between the charged and uncharged objects. Option D is incorrect because charging by radiation is not a standard method of charging in static electricity at this level.

questions.question_text: A material has conductivity between that of metals and insulators, and its ability to conduct electricity can be changed by adding impurities. This material is best classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The material described is a semiconductor. The two key features â intermediate conductivity between metals and insulators, and the ability to change conductivity by adding impurities (a process called doping) â are defining characteristics of semiconductors. Materials like silicon and germanium are semiconductors, and they are the foundation of modern electronics like computer chips and solar cells.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because conductors like metals have high conductivity and do not need impurities to conduct electricity. Option B is wrong because insulators have very low conductivity and adding impurities does not significantly change their behaviour. Option D is incorrect because magnetic properties are unrelated to electrical conductivity classification.

questions.question_text: A subatomic particle is found inside the nucleus, has a mass nearly equal to that of a proton, and carries no electric charge. This particle is classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: The particle described is a neutron. The three features â location inside the nucleus, mass nearly equal to a proton, and no electric charge â are all characteristic of neutrons. Neutrons are electrically neutral subatomic particles that, along with protons, form the nucleus of an atom. Their neutral nature means they do not participate in electrostatic interactions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because electrons are found outside the nucleus, have very small mass compared to protons, and carry a negative charge. Option B is wrong because protons carry a positive charge, not zero charge. Option D is incorrect because photons are particles of light with no mass and no charge, and they are not found inside the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Riya is walking home from school during monsoon season when she notices dark clouds forming and hears distant thunder. She is carrying a metal umbrella. What should Riya do to stay safe?

options.text: Open the metal umbrella and continue walking
Stand under the tallest tree nearby for shelter
Close the umbrella, move to a low-lying area, and crouch down away from tall objects
Hold the umbrella high above her head to stay dry

questions.explanation_correct: Riya should close her metal umbrella, move to a low-lying area, and crouch down away from tall objects. During a thunderstorm, a metal umbrella can act as a conductor and attract lightning. Standing under tall trees is also dangerous because lightning tends to strike tall objects. The safest approach is to make yourself as small a target as possible by crouching low in an open area away from tall structures and metal objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is dangerous because a metal umbrella can attract lightning due to its metallic tip acting as a conductor. Option B is unsafe because tall trees are likely targets for lightning, and standing under one increases the risk of being struck. Option D is extremely dangerous as holding a metal object high up makes it even more likely to attract a lightning strike.

questions.question_text: Amit rubs a plastic scale on his woollen sweater during a dry winter day at school. He then brings the scale near tiny pieces of paper on his desk. The pieces of paper jump up and stick to the scale. Which method of charging explains the paper sticking to the scale?

options.text: The paper is charged by friction with the desk
The paper is charged by induction due to the nearby charged scale
The paper is charged by conduction when it touches the scale
The paper becomes magnetic due to the scale

questions.explanation_correct: When Amit brings the charged scale near the paper pieces, the scale's charge induces a temporary charge separation in the paper through induction. The side of the paper closer to the scale develops an opposite charge to the scale, creating an attractive force. Since the attracted side is closer, the attractive force is stronger than the repulsive force on the far side, and the paper jumps up and sticks to the scale. This is charging by induction, not friction or conduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the paper was not rubbed against anything, so it was not charged by friction. Option C is wrong because the paper was attracted before touching the scale; the initial attraction happens through induction, not conduction. Option D is incorrect because static electricity and magnetism are different phenomena â the scale does not become magnetic when rubbed.

questions.question_text: Priya performs an experiment in the school laboratory. She charges an ebonite rod by rubbing it with fur and then touches the metal disc of a gold leaf electroscope with the rod. The leaves diverge. She then touches the metal disc with her finger. What will happen to the leaves?

options.text: The leaves will diverge even more
The leaves will remain in the same position

questions.explanation_correct: When Priya touches the metal disc with her finger, her body acts as a conductor connected to the ground (earthing). The excess charge on the electroscope flows through her body to the earth, neutralising the electroscope. As the charge is lost, the leaves no longer repel each other and collapse back together. This process of removing charge by connecting to the earth through a conductor is called earthing or grounding.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because touching the disc with a finger provides a path for charge to escape, reducing rather than increasing the charge. Option C is wrong because the human body is a conductor and will definitely allow charge to flow away from the electroscope. Option D is incorrect because there is no mechanism to cause vibration; the charge simply dissipates through the body to the ground.

questions.question_text: During a monsoon thunderstorm, Rohan notices that the lightning conductor on his apartment building has a pointed metal tip at the top connected by a thick copper strip running down to a metal plate buried in the ground. Why is the copper strip thick rather than thin?

options.text: A thick strip looks better on the building
A thick strip can safely carry the very large current from a lightning strike without melting
A thick strip prevents rain from entering the building
A thick strip attracts more lightning

questions.explanation_correct: A lightning strike carries an enormous amount of electrical current in a very short time. A thick copper strip has low resistance and a large cross-sectional area, which allows it to safely conduct this massive current to the ground without overheating or melting. If the strip were too thin, the intense current could cause it to heat up rapidly and melt, failing to protect the building and potentially causing a fire.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the thickness of the strip is a safety feature, not an aesthetic choice. Option C is wrong because the copper strip is not related to waterproofing â that is the job of the building's roof and walls. Option D is incorrect because the thickness of the strip does not affect whether lightning is attracted; the pointed tip at the top serves that purpose.

questions.question_text: Meera is dressing up for a school function and notices that when she removes her polyester dupatta quickly, it crackles and clings to her cotton kurta. She also sees tiny sparks in a dark room. What causes these sparks?

options.text: The fabric catches fire due to friction
The discharge of static charge accumulated by friction between the two fabrics
The polyester produces its own light
The cotton kurta is a conductor and creates electricity

questions.explanation_correct: When Meera quickly removes her polyester dupatta, friction between the polyester and cotton fabrics causes electrons to transfer from one fabric to the other, building up static charge on both surfaces. The crackling sound and tiny sparks occur when this accumulated static charge discharges through the air. The sparks are small-scale versions of lightning â a sudden flow of charge through the air gap between the two fabrics, briefly ionising the air and producing light and sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the temperature from normal rubbing of fabrics is far too low to cause a fire. Option C is wrong because polyester does not produce its own light; the light comes from the electrical discharge. Option D is incorrect because cotton is actually a poor conductor of electricity, and the phenomenon is caused by static charge buildup from friction, not current generation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about charging by friction is NOT correct?

options.text: Electrons are transferred from one object to another
The two objects acquire opposite charges
Protons move from one object to the other during rubbing
Friction between the surfaces causes the charge transfer

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that protons move from one object to another during friction is NOT correct. This is a common misconception among students. Protons are tightly bound inside the nucleus of atoms and cannot be removed by simple rubbing. During charging by friction, only electrons, which are on the outer shells of atoms, are transferred from one surface to the other. The other three statements are all correct descriptions of charging by friction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct statements about charging by friction. Electrons are indeed transferred (A), the two objects do acquire opposite charges because one gains electrons and the other loses them (B), and friction between surfaces is the mechanism that enables the transfer (D). The only incorrect statement is C, because protons never move during friction â they remain locked in the nucleus.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about electric charges is NOT correct?

options.text: A charged object can attract an uncharged object
If two objects attract each other, both must be charged
An atom is electrically neutral because it has equal protons and electrons

questions.explanation_correct: The statement 'If two objects attract each other, both must be charged' is NOT correct. This is a widespread misconception. A charged object can attract an uncharged object through electrostatic induction. The charged object induces a temporary charge separation in the uncharged object, making the near side have an opposite charge and causing attraction. So attraction does not necessarily mean both objects are charged â only one needs to be charged to create an attractive force.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B, and D are all correct. Like charges do repel (A). A charged object can indeed attract an uncharged object through induction (B). An atom is neutral because it has equal numbers of protons and electrons (D). The misconception in option C is common â students often assume that attraction means both objects must carry charge, but induction allows a charged body to attract a neutral one.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a safe practice during a thunderstorm?

options.text: Staying inside a building away from windows
Crouching low if caught outdoors with no shelter nearby

questions.explanation_correct: Lying flat on open ground is NOT a safe practice during a thunderstorm. This is a common misconception â students often think that lying flat makes you a smaller target. However, lying flat actually increases your contact area with the ground, which means ground currents from a nearby lightning strike can flow through more of your body. The recommended position is to crouch low with feet together, minimising both your height and ground contact. The other options are all genuinely safe practices.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, C, and D are all safe practices. Staying inside a building (A) provides protection from lightning. Avoiding electrical appliances (C) is wise because lightning can travel through wiring. Crouching low with feet together (D) minimises your height as a target while keeping ground contact area small. Only option B is unsafe because lying flat increases ground contact area and exposure to ground currents from lightning strikes.

questions.question_text: Why does a lightning conductor have a pointed tip at the top rather than a flat or rounded end?

options.text: A pointed tip looks more attractive on buildings
A pointed tip concentrates the electric charge, making it easier to discharge into the air and attract lightning safely
A pointed tip is lighter and cheaper to manufacture
A pointed tip prevents rain from collecting on the conductor

questions.explanation_correct: A pointed tip is used on lightning conductors because electric charge concentrates at sharp points. This high concentration of charge at the tip creates a strong electric field that ionises the surrounding air, facilitating a controlled discharge. When a thundercloud approaches, the pointed tip can initiate a discharge path before a full lightning bolt develops, effectively guiding the lightning safely through the conductor and into the ground. A flat or rounded end would not concentrate charge as effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the pointed tip is a scientific design choice for charge concentration, not an aesthetic one. Option C is wrong because the choice of shape is based on electrostatic principles, not cost or weight. Option D is incorrect because preventing rain accumulation is not the purpose â the pointed shape is specifically designed to concentrate charge and facilitate controlled electrical discharge.

questions.question_text: Why do the gold leaves of an electroscope diverge when a charged object is brought near the metal disc?

options.text: Because the gold leaves become magnetic
Because the charged object pushes the leaves apart with wind
Because charges are induced on the leaves, giving both leaves the same type of charge, and like charges repel
Because the gold leaves absorb heat from the charged object and expand

questions.explanation_correct: When a charged object is brought near the metal disc of an electroscope, it induces charge separation in the electroscope through induction. For example, if a negatively charged rod is brought near the disc, electrons in the metal are repelled downward towards the leaves. Both leaves accumulate the same type of charge (negative in this case). Since like charges repel each other, the two leaves push apart and diverge. This divergence is a direct result of electrostatic repulsion between the identically charged leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because the electroscope works on electrostatic principles, not magnetism. Option B is wrong because there is no air movement or wind involved â the force is electrostatic. Option D is incorrect because heat expansion plays no role in electroscope function. The leaves diverge purely due to the repulsion between like charges induced on both leaves.

questions.question_text: Why does a plastic comb attract small pieces of paper after being rubbed with dry hair?

options.text: Because rubbing makes the comb magnetic
Because the comb becomes wet and the paper sticks to moisture
Because rubbing transfers electrons to the comb, making it charged, and the charged comb induces opposite charge on the near side of the paper, causing attraction
Because the paper is always negatively charged

questions.explanation_correct: When the plastic comb is rubbed with dry hair, electrons are transferred from the hair to the comb by friction, giving the comb a negative charge. When this charged comb is brought near pieces of paper, it induces a charge separation in the paper through induction. The side of the paper closest to the comb develops a positive charge (as electrons in the paper are repelled away), while the far side becomes negative. Since the positive side is closer to the negative comb, the attractive force is stronger than the repulsive force, and the paper is attracted to the comb.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because rubbing does not make objects magnetic â it creates static electric charge. Option B is wrong because the attraction is electrical, not due to moisture. Option D is incorrect because paper is normally uncharged (neutral); it only develops a temporary charge separation when a charged object is brought near it through induction.
